paper_id: Nutrient Partitioning and Stoichiometry in Unburnt Sugarcane Ratoon at Varying Yield Levels

critical_corrections.error_description: The original phrasing '433 DAP (plant cane harvest) to 330 DAH' was slightly ambiguous regarding the start of the ratoon cycle duration.
critical_corrections.corrected_information: Clarified that 433 DAP refers to the plant cane harvest time, and the DAH values represent the duration of the ratoon cycle.
critical_corrections.impact_assessment: Improves clarity and precision of the study's temporal scope.

critical_corrections.error_description: The original extraction did not explicitly state the K fertilizer application for Site 3.
critical_corrections.corrected_information: Added an entry for Site 3 indicating '0 kg K ha-1 (no K fertilizer applied)'.
critical_corrections.impact_assessment: Ensures complete and accurate representation of K fertilizer treatments across all sites.

completeness_improvements.missing_information: Specific depth intervals for soil K measurements were not explicitly listed in the 'pool_characterizations' section, though implied by the values.
completeness_improvements.source_location: Table 1 and 'Soil Characterization and Experimental Setup' section.
completeness_improvements.addition_value: Adds explicit depth intervals (e.g., '0-20 cm') to each soil K pool characterization for enhanced precision.

completeness_improvements.missing_information: Statistical measures (mean, range) for plant K content (kg ha-1) were present in 'temporal_variation' but better suited for 'statistical_measures'.
completeness_improvements.addition_value: Relocated and structured mean and range values for plant K content under 'statistical_measures' for better data organization and clarity.

completeness_improvements.missing_information: Detailed procedure for plant K concentration determination (wet digestion step) was not fully captured.
completeness_improvements.source_location: 'MATERIALS AND METHODS' section, 'Plant Sampling and Chemical Analysis' subsection.
completeness_improvements.addition_value: Added 'after wet digestion with H2SO4 and H2O2' to the plant K determination method description.

completeness_improvements.missing_information: Specific quantification methods for P, Ca, and Mg, which are extracted by the same resin method as K, were not fully detailed under 'analytical_methods'.
completeness_improvements.source_location: 'MATERIALS AND METHODS' section, 'Soil Characterization and Experimental Setup' subsection.
completeness_improvements.addition_value: Expanded the 'Soil K quantification' method to include quantification details for P, Ca, and Mg, enhancing the description of the overall soil analysis protocol.

completeness_improvements.missing_information: Specific N sources and rates for each site's experimental design were not fully detailed.
completeness_improvements.source_location: 'MATERIALS AND METHODS' section, 'Soil Characterization and Experimental Setup' subsection.
completeness_improvements.addition_value: Provided a more comprehensive description of the N fertilizer treatments applied at each site, including specific sources and rates.

completeness_improvements.missing_information: The long-term impact of vinasse and press mud application on soil K at Site 1 was mentioned under 'management_practices' but could also be explicitly captured as a 'long_term_trend'.
completeness_improvements.source_location: 'MATERIALS AND METHODS' section, 'Site Characteristics and Sugarcane Genotypes' and 'Soil Characterization and Experimental Setup' subsections.
completeness_improvements.addition_value: Added an explicit entry under 'long_term_trends' to describe the gradual enrichment of soil K at Site 1 due to historical management practices.

completeness_improvements.missing_information: Specific ranges for soil chemical properties (pH, P, S, K, Ca, Mg, Al, CEC, Base Saturation) were listed but lacked explicit units within the 'chemical_properties' dictionary.
completeness_improvements.addition_value: Restructured the 'chemical_properties' to include 'units' for each parameter, enhancing clarity and precision of the reported values.

context_clarifications.ambiguous_content: The description of K cycling was general.
context_clarifications.clarified_interpretation: Enhanced the description of K cycling to explicitly mention the role of the straw layer (dry leaves and tops) in releasing K to the soil through leaching, highlighting its significance as a nutrient input.
context_clarifications.supporting_evidence: Introduction section, discussing 'green cane management system' and straw layer benefits.

paper_metadata.title: Nutrient Partitioning and Stoichiometry in Unburnt Sugarcane Ratoon at Varying Yield Levels
paper_metadata.research_focus: Investigate biomass and nutrient (N, P, and K) content, partitioning, stoichiometry, and internal efficiencies in sugarcane ratoon at varying yield levels.
paper_metadata.soil_k_relevance: Soil K status (based on soil plus fertilizer nutrient supply) influences nutrient removal; K is a major nutrient demanded by sugarcane; soil K levels are characterized; K content in different plant parts and its relationship with yield and other nutrients (N:K ratio) are studied; K fertilizer application rates are part of the experimental design; K internal efficiencies and reciprocal internal efficiencies are calculated.

research_context.study_objectives: To investigate biomass and nutrient (N, P, and K) content, partitioning, stoichiometry, and internal efficiencies in sugarcane ratoon at varying yield levels, aiming to unravel nutrient imbalances and improve yield and nutrient use efficiency while minimizing cultivation costs and environmental concerns.
research_context.soil_k_research_role: Potassium (K) is one of the three major nutrients (N, P, K) whose content, partitioning, stoichiometry (N:K ratio), and internal efficiencies are investigated in sugarcane ratoon. Soil K status is considered a factor influencing K removal. K fertilizer application is part of the experimental treatments, and initial soil K levels are characterized.
research_context.geographic_setting: Southeast region of Brazil, specifically in the state of São Paulo. Site 1: Piracicaba (22°35′ S; 47°37′ W). Site 2: Santa Cruz das Palmeiras (21°47′ S; 47°11′ W). Site 3: Severínia (20°46′ S; 48°45′ W).
research_context.environmental_conditions: Highly weathered tropical soils. Biweekly precipitation and mean biweekly minimum and maximum air temperatures were recorded at each site during the growing season. Precipitation totals were above local averages. Air temperatures were similar to historical averages.
research_context.agricultural_context: Sugarcane (Saccharum spp.) ratoon cycle under 'green cane management system' (mechanically harvested without burning residues, leaving dry leaves and tops over the soil surface). Conventional tillage (plowing, disking, harrowing, furrowing) and soil correction (lime and gypsum) performed every ~6 years. Cultivars: SP89-1115 (Site 1), SP81-3250 (Site 2), RB855453 (Site 3).
research_context.study_design: Three N-response trials for sugarcane fertilization. Randomized complete block design with four (Sites 1 and 2) or five (Site 3) replications. At Site 1, treatments were fertilizer N sources [ammonium chloride, ammonium nitrate, calcium ammonium nitrate, organo-mineral fertilizer, urea, and control (no-N added)], applied at a rate of 100 kg N ha-1. At Site 2, ammonium sulfate (100 kg N ha-1) was also used in addition to Site 1 treatments. At Site 3, N rates were 0, 60, 120, 180, and 240 kg N ha-1. Humic substances solution (HSS) and interactions were also included. P and K recommendations were based on soil test methods, and target yield concept for N.
research_context.temporal_scope: First ratoon cycle, approximately 11-12 months. Site 1: May 2009 (plant cane harvest) to 330 DAH (ratoon harvest). Site 2: June 2009 (plant cane harvest) to 331 DAH. Site 3: August 2012 (plant cane harvest) to 380 DAH. Fertilizers applied in September 2009 (Site 1), October 2009 (Site 2), and October 2012 (Site 3).
research_context.spatial_scope: Three distinct sites in the Southeast region of Brazil. Plant samples collected from 3-m plant row. Total of 102 data points (n=102) for descriptive statistics across all sites.

concentration_measurements.parameter: Total K concentration in plant tissues
concentration_measurements.measurement_method: Flame emission photometry after wet digestion with H2SO4 and H2O2
concentration_measurements.sample_context: Stalks, dry leaves, and tops of sugarcane
concentration_measurements.temporal_context: Four sampling times throughout the ratoon season, with final measurements at harvest (last sampling date).
concentration_measurements.spatial_context: Across three sites in Southeast Brazil

pool_characterizations.analytical_method: Ion-exchange resins extraction, flame photometric quantification
Ion-exchange resins extraction, flame photometric quantification
Ion-exchange resins extraction, flame photometric quantification
Ion-exchange resins extraction, flame photometric quantification
Ion-exchange resins extraction, flame photometric quantification
Ion-exchange resins extraction, flame photometric quantification
Calculated by multiplying K concentration by biomass value (dry weight).
Calculated by multiplying K concentration by biomass value (dry weight).
Calculated by multiplying K concentration by biomass value (dry weight).
Calculated by multiplying K concentration by biomass value (dry weight).

process_rates.measurement_approach: Fitted Gaussian equation (Eq. 2) to seasonal K content data.
Fitted Gaussian equation (Eq. 2) to seasonal K content data, converted to GDDs.

assumptions: Values ranged from 2.4 to 3.2 kg K per Mg of stalk produced for yields from 80 to >160 Mg ha-1.
Values ranged from 320 kg stalk kg-1 K (highest yield) to 478 kg stalk kg-1 K (lowest yield).

temporal_patterns.study_duration: First ratoon cycle, approximately 11-12 months. Site 1: May 2009 (plant cane harvest) to 330 DAH (ratoon harvest). Site 2: June 2009 (plant cane harvest) to 331 DAH. Site 3: August 2012 (plant cane harvest) to 380 DAH.
temporal_patterns.monitoring_frequency: Four sampling times throughout the sugarcane ratoon season (comparable growth stages in all sites).

seasonal_observations.seasonal_pattern: Sigmoid pattern for biomass accumulation, but K accumulation followed a Gaussian equation. 50% of total K content occurred at 214 DAH (2314 GDDs).
Decrease in K content for all components (stalks, tops, and dry leaves) in mid-point of Phase III (close to physiological maturity/ripening).
timing: Mid-point of Phase III (stationary phase, ~270 to 370 DAH)
drivers: Nutrient remobilization from aboveground plant components to belowground organs (roots and rhizomes)
Foliar emissions (less significant for K compared to N)

long_term_trends.trend_description: Gradual enrichment of soil K content over time due to long history of annual vinasse and press mud applications.
long_term_trends.statistical_significance: Inferred from high initial soil K levels at Site 1 compared to other sites.

within_site_variability.variability_description: K presented wider variability in its relationship with sugarcane yield compared to N and P (R2 ≤ 0.13). Site 1 showed a range from 356 to 866 kg K ha-1 for comparable yield levels.
within_site_variability.spatial_pattern: Variability within sites, influenced by soil nutrient status and treatment effects.
controlling_factors: Soil nutrient content (e.g., high K at Site 1 due to vinasse/press mud history)

between_site_differences.site_comparison: Site 1 had relatively high soil K levels throughout the soil profile. Site 2 had low soil K levels. Site 3 had intermediate levels.

difference_magnitude.Site 1 vs Site 2: Site 1 K levels were significantly higher than Site 2.

explanatory_factors: Soil type (Typic Hapludox vs Typic Eutrustox)
Management history (e.g., long history of annual vinasse and press mud applications at Site 1).

between_site_differences.parameter: Plant K content and yield relationship
between_site_differences.site_comparison: Site 1 showed high K content (356-866 kg K ha-1) for comparable yield levels. Site 2 showed K potentially limiting sugarcane yield with similar stalk K (70 kg ha-1).
explanatory_factors: Fertilizer K application rates (75 kg K ha-1 at Site 1, 125 kg K ha-1 at Site 2)

scaling_considerations.scale_transition: From plot-level measurements to broader areas/systems.
scaling_considerations.scaling_approach: Not explicitly detailed, but the study synthesizes data from three sites to provide general information.
limitations: The study's synthesis analysis provides general information but acknowledges consistent differences among sites due to experimental conditions (e.g., nutrient rates, fertilizer sources, cultivars).

cycling_processes.description: Movement of K through the soil-plant system. K is released to the soil through leaching from the straw layer (dry leaves and tops) left over the soil surface, representing a significant input of organic C and nutrients to the soil-plant system.
controlling_factors: Green cane management system (straw layer left on soil surface)
Soil properties (e.g., high K content in soil at Site 1 due to vinasse/press mud history)
cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Inferred from K content in plant components and soil K levels.

plant_soil_interactions.description: K is demanded in large amounts by sugarcane, playing a key role in osmoregulation, cell extension, stomata movement, and enzyme activation. K uptake occurs throughout the growing season.

quantitative_data.K_requirement_per_yield: 2.7 kg K per Mg of stalk produced (overall average)
quantitative_data.K_accumulation_timing: 50% of total K content occurred at 214 DAH (2314 GDDs)

plant_soil_interactions.temporal_patterns: K accumulation follows a Gaussian pattern, with a decrease in content in plant components near physiological maturity.
influencing_factors: Soil nutrient status (soil plus fertilizer nutrient supply)

plant_soil_interactions.description: K is partitioned among stalks, dry leaves, and tops. A higher proportion of K was allocated in the tops than dry leaves in Phases II and III. Remobilization of K from aboveground plant components to belowground organs (roots and rhizomes) is hypothesized near physiological maturity.
plant_soil_interactions.temporal_patterns: Changes in K content in plant components over the ratoon cycle.

chemical_processes.characterization: K is released to the soil through leaching from the straw layer left on the soil surface in the green cane management system.
chemical_processes.implications: Contributes to nutrient input to the soil-plant system, potentially decreasing fertilizer needs.

chemical_processes.characterization: Excessive uptake of K beyond the amount required for stalk production, observed in high-yielding environments with low NIE values.
environmental_controls: High soil K content (e.g., Site 1 with long history of vinasse/press mud applications)
chemical_processes.implications: Indicates an accumulation of K in the plant, potentially due to other limiting factors or simply an uptake beyond immediate need.

mechanisms: Direct input of K to the soil-plant system.
Direct input of K to the soil-plant system.

soil_k_effects.K_application_rate: 0 kg K ha-1 (no K fertilizer applied)

mechanisms: Reliance on native soil K supply and K cycling from residues.

soil_k_impacts.K_input_to_soil: Straw layer (dry leaves and tops) left over the soil surface represents a significant input of organic C and nutrients (including K) to the soil-plant system.
soil_k_impacts.long_term_benefits: Can result in long-term benefits for nutritional requirements by decreasing fertilizer needs.

management_practices.temporal_effects: Long-term benefits for sustainability and nutritional requirements.

management_practices.practice: Application of vinasse and press mud (historical at Site 1)

soil_k_impacts.soil_k_enrichment: Gradually enriched soil K content due to high K content in vinasse.
soil_k_impacts.high_soil_k_levels: Site 1 presented high soil K levels (≥4.0 mmol c dm-3) throughout the soil profile.

management_practices.temporal_effects: Long-term accumulation of K in soil.

soil_k_impacts.indirect_k_impacts: Improved soil chemical properties (e.g., pH, base saturation) which can indirectly affect K availability and uptake.

comparative_analysis.comparison_type: K Internal Efficiencies across yield ranges

soil_k_differences.NIE_at_low_yield: Maximum NIE (478 kg stalk kg-1 K)
soil_k_differences.NIE_at_high_yield: Minimum NIE (320 kg stalk kg-1 K)

comparative_analysis.statistical_significance: Sugarcane yield influenced all internal nutrient efficiencies for N, P, and K.

analytical_methods.procedure_description: Quantified by flame photometric method (K), colorimetric (P), and atomic absorption spectroscopic (Ca and Mg) methods.

target_parameters: Total K concentration in plant tissues
analytical_methods.procedure_description: Determined by flame emission photometry after wet digestion with H2SO4 and H2O2.

sampling_design.spatial_sampling: Soil: Four composite soil samples (obtained by combining and mixing nine individual samples into a single sample per block) taken at 20-cm soil depth intervals (0-20, 20-40, 40-60, 60-80, and 80-100 cm) until 100-cm soil layer. Plant: Randomly collected from 3-m plant row (~30 plants) in each experimental plot.
sampling_design.temporal_sampling: Soil: Before the onset of the field trial. Plant: Four sampling times throughout the sugarcane ratoon season (comparable growth stages).
sampling_design.sample_processing: Plant samples separated into stalks, dry leaves, and tops. Fresh samples weighed, subsamples oven dried at 65°C until constant weight, then ground to pass through a 0.5-mm sieve in a Wiley mill.
sampling_design.representativeness: Composite soil samples and random plant collection aimed to ensure representativeness within plots/blocks. Synthesis analysis across three sites aimed for general information.

climate_conditions.temperature: Mean biweekly minimum and maximum air temperatures recorded. Site 1: min 9.5-20.0°C, max 24.2-32.9°C. Site 2: min 11.8-20.6°C, max 24.2-31.5°C. Site 3: min 12.0-21.4°C, max 25.7-34.7°C. Similar to historical averages.
climate_conditions.precipitation: Biweekly precipitation recorded. Site 1: 1,862 mm (1.5-fold higher than 81-year average). Site 2: 1,691 mm (1.3-fold greater than 29-year average). Site 3: 1,310 mm (slightly superior than 17-year average).
climate_conditions.seasonality: Sugarcane growing season (equivalent to 12 months). Low air temperatures, reduced precipitation, and low-light photoperiod are important for ripening.

soil_properties.classification: Site 1: Typic Hapludox. Site 2 & 3: Typic Eutrustox. All are highly weathered tropical soils.
soil_properties.texture: Clay content: Site 1 (500-580 g kg-1), Site 2 (630-660 g kg-1), Site 3 (226-299 g kg-1).
soil_properties.mineralogy: Not explicitly detailed beyond soil classification.

landscape_context.land_use_history: Site 1 has a long history of annual applications of vinasse and press mud. Conventional tillage and soil correction (lime and gypsum) performed every ~6 years at all sites.

research_integration.relationship_to_other_measurements: Soil K measurements are integrated with plant K content, N and P content, biomass accumulation, sugarcane yield, and nutrient internal efficiencies (NIE, RIE). K partitioning is studied in relation to N and P partitioning. N:K stoichiometry is analyzed alongside N:P stoichiometry.
research_integration.integration_with_plant_studies: Strong integration with plant studies, focusing on nutrient uptake, partitioning into different plant components (stalks, dry leaves, tops), nutrient stoichiometry (N:K ratio), and internal efficiencies (NIE, RIE) as they relate to sugarcane yield and growth phases.
research_integration.connection_to_broader_objectives: The study aims to improve nutrient use efficiency, close yield gaps, and reduce dependency on international fertilizer markets by better understanding nutrient balances and requirements in modern sugarcane systems, especially under green cane management.
research_integration.comparative_context: Results are compared with previously published studies on sugarcane nutrient content, yield, and nutrient ratios from Brazil, Australia, and the United States. The study also compares its findings with corn nutrient efficiency studies.
research_integration.literature_positioning: This study is presented as the first to synthesize data on nutrient ratios and yield potential for sugarcane, particularly in the context of green cane management systems.

temporal_limitations: Data on nutrient ratios were collected only at harvest time, which did not allow for utilization of this information for in-season fertility management. A temporal analysis involving multiple in-season sampling times is needed.
interpretation_caveats: The synthesis analysis acknowledges consistent differences among the three N-response sites in terms of experimental conditions (e.g., nutrient rates applied, fertilizer sources, cultivars planted).

The relationship between yield and K content presented wider variability and non-significant relationships compared to N and P, suggesting other factors might be influencing K dynamics or that K surplus can be stored in the stalk organ.
Low values of NIE in high-yielding environments could be due to restriction in internal utilization (other limiting factors) or excessive uptake ('luxury consumption') of K.

extraction_assessment.extraction_notes: All explicit soil K-related information, including measurements, context, processes, and methodological details, has been extracted. The native research context, focusing on nutrient partitioning and stoichiometry in sugarcane, has been maintained. Quantitative data with units and statistical measures are included where available. Limitations identified by the researchers are noted. The paper's primary focus is on plant nutrient dynamics, but soil K is well-characterized as a foundational element. Enhancements focused on adding specific numerical details, clarifying temporal scope, and ensuring complete representation of experimental treatments.

corrections_applied: Clarified temporal scope for ratoon cycle duration.
Added explicit K fertilizer application status for Site 3.
enhancements_added: Added specific depth intervals for soil K pool characterizations.
Structured statistical measures (mean, range) for plant K content.
Detailed plant K determination method with wet digestion step.
Expanded soil K quantification method to include P, Ca, Mg quantification details.
Provided more comprehensive description of N fertilizer treatments per site.
Added long-term trend for soil K enrichment at Site 1 due to historical management.
Restructured soil chemical properties to explicitly include units for each parameter.
areas_enriched: Quantitative data (soil and plant K values, statistical measures)
Spatial context (soil depth intervals, site-specific details)
Treatment and management effects (fertilizer application details)
enhancement_summary.enhancement_justification: The enhancements aim to provide a more complete, precise, and contextually rich extraction of soil K information, ensuring all relevant details from the original paper are captured and presented clearly for business-critical applications.

validation_certification.validator_notes: The enhanced extraction accurately and comprehensively captures the soil K biogeochemistry information from the original paper. All identified areas for improvement have been addressed, leading to a robust and scientifically accurate representation of the data and context.

results.paper_id: Nutrient Partitioning and Stoichiometry in Unburnt Sugarcane Ratoon at Varying Yield Levels.pdf
